did.unittitle: History of Medicine picture file 1523-2002 and undated
did.langmaterial: Material in English, French, Latin, Dutch, German
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Assembled by the staff of the Duke University Medical Library, the History of Medicine Picture File dates from the 1500s to 2002 and offers thousands of small and large images of individuals, places, and subjects, with the great majority portraying physicians, scientists, nurses, and other individuals related to the history or practice of medicine. Places featured include hospitals and other institutions of medicine, and scenes related to events in medical history. Subject categories include advertising, anatomy, books, caricatures, childbirth, embryology, medical instruments, pediatrics, physicians, and surgery, among many others. The predominant formats are engravings, lithographs, print materials (such as posters, clippings, and postcards), and modern photographic prints, but there are also albumen photographs, negatives, and other image formats found throughout the files. Items were acquired by the Duke Medical Library from various sources over many decades and functioned as a vertical file for library students and researchers. Forms part of the History of Medicine Collections at Duke University.

note.label: Language of Materials
note.p: Language: Material in English, French, Latin, Dutch, German

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: However, collection may contain materials to which the Acknowledgment of Legal Responsibilities and Privacy Rights form applies. Patrons must sign this form before using this collection.
Also, all or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. Consequently, there may be a 24-hour delay in obtaining these materials.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The History of Medicine picture file was received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a transfer from the Medical Center Library in 2011.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Levi Crews, Joanne Fairhurst, Paula Jeannet Mangiafico, Matthew Warren, January 2014
Encoded by Joanne Fairhurst, Paula Jeannet Mangiafico, Matthew Warren, February 2014
All older Medical Center Library accessions and Rubenstein Library accession 2013-0034 are described in this finding aid.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The History of Medicine Picture File was assembled as a reference and research resource by Duke University Medical Library staff over several decades and formed part of the History of Medicine Collections. The majority of the items were received as gifts and acquisitions from various individuals, many of whom were affiliated with Duke University and the School of Medicine, most notably Dr. Josiah Trent and Henry Schumann.

The Duke University History of Medicine Collections acquire, preserve, interpret, and make available for research and instruction, materials documenting the history of medicine, biomedical science, health and disease in the global context of the Western medical tradition.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Assembled by the staff of the Duke University Medical Library, the History of Medicine Picture File offers thousands of images of individuals, places, and subjects dating from the 1500s to 2002, with the great majority portraying physicians, scientists, nurses, and other individuals related to the history or practice of medicine. Places featured include hospitals and other institutions of medicine, and scenes related to events in medical history. Subject categories include advertising, anatomy, books, caricature, childbirth, embryology, medical instruments, pediatrics, physicians, and surgery, among many others.

Most of the images measure in size under 10 x 12 inches, but there are approximately 500 larger pieces. The predominant formats are engravings, lithographs, cartoons, clippings from magazines and newspapers, and modern photographic prints, but there are also albumen photographs and other image formats found throughout the files. Items were acquired by the Duke Medical Library from various sources over many decades and functioned as a vertical file for library students and researchers.

The oversize items range in size from 11 x 15 to 23 x 30 inches, and offer a varied assemblage of portraits, caricatures, posters, broadsides, and reproductions of artwork, in black-and-white and in color. Items include portraits and scenes with notable physicians; illustrations of various medical practices, procedures, and instruments; anatomical views, some possibly as early as the 17th century; medical advertisements and promotional literature; depictions of events in medical history in Europe and North America; caricatures; 20th century illustrations for book covers; and many other topics.

Images and prints are often accompanied by reproduction negatives and slides created by Medical Center Library staff. Many of the images in this collection were also scanned by Medical Library staff and are available through the Medical Center Library & Archives Duke Medicine Digital Repository database. For more information, please contact the History of Medicine Curator at the Rubenstein Library.
Acquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections at Duke University.

did.unittitle: History of Medicine Picture File: People Series

scopecontent.p: Series contains images of significant anatomists, chemists, physicians, biologists, and other individuals in the field of medicine, arranged alphabetically by last name. Most depict 19th century men, primarily from European nations, particularly Germany, England, France, and Italy, and from North America, but there are also individuals active as early as the 15th century and as late as the 20th century. In many cases there are multiple images of the same individual in the folder.

The predominant formats are engravings, lithographs, modern black-and-white photographs, and printed images (chiefly clippings on glossy paper), but there are other formats present such as albumen prints and negatives. Oftentimes the image is a modern photographic reproduction of an engraving, painting, sculpture, or other work. Images are also often accompanied by a slide or negative reproduction created as far back as the 1960s by Duke University Medical Center Library staff. Sizes range from small prints ranging from 2 x 3 to 10 x 12 inches, to oversize items of up to 23 x 30 inches. The sizes of oversize boxes are given in the container inventory.

Many of the items have been digitized and can be found through the Medical Center Library & Archives Historical Images in Medicine (HIM) database. Please contact the History of Medicine Curator for information on the digital images.

did.unittitle: Old-Time Boston Doctors on 'Ether Day', from Boston Globe, 1940

scopecontent.p: Photograph of approximately 40 prominent physicians, many of them active in Massachusetts, gathered in 1896 for 50th anniversary of use of ether in surgery. Includes Silas Weir Mitchell, Charles P. Curtis, Henry Bowditch, Abraham Jacobi, Sidney Otis, Lord and Lady Playfair, Isaac Galloupe, Benjamin Cotting, William J. Morton, F.C. Shattuck, William H. Welch, and others. Newspaper cutting mounted on board.

Comes with pamphlet, Hinckley's Who Was Who on Ether Day, from an exhibit at Boston Library, 1962, describing the protagonists in Hinckley's famous painting of the first public demonstration of ether as an anesthetic.
Includes slide.
Also contains picture of Mayow, John.

did.unittitle: Johns Hopkins Medical School Pathology Department photos, 1921-circa 1930

scopecontent.p: Black-and-white photos, chiefly of groups of Pathology staff. One photo circa 1930 depicts doctors gathered in medical lab, and reads: "Tuesday morning conference in the old autopsy room...the material used at these conferences during 1930 was brought to Duke and formed the basis of the origin of Duke collection [used?] for the first class in Pathology in 1931."

Horine is shown in black-and-white photo with three other men, one of whom is most likely Henry Schumman, rare book dealer, to whom the image is inscribed, June 1948. They are examining the publication Pioneer Life in Kentucky, written by Daniel Drake and published by Schumann in 1948.

did.unittitle: History of Medicine Picture File: Places Series

scopecontent.p: Series mostly contains images of medical schools, colleges, and hospitals in England, Europe, and the United States. Series also contains images of other locations significant to medicine and/or the history of medicine. Arranged alphabetically by place name or title. In most cases, titles are from original image or folder.

As with other series, the predominant formats are engravings, lithographs, and modern photographs, but there are other formats present such as postcards and negatives. Images are also often accompanied by a slide or negative reproduction created by Medical Library staff. Sizes range from under 10x12 inches up to 18x24 inches. The sizes of oversize boxes are given in the container inventory.

Many of the items have been digitized and can be found through the Medical Center Library & Archives Historical Images in Medicine (HIM) database. Please contact the History of Medicine Collections Curator for information on the digital images.

did.unittitle: Yellow Sulphur Springs, Montgomery County, Virginia, color lithograph by Ed Beyer, from "Album of Virginia," 1857
History of Medicine Picture File: Subjects Series

scopecontent.p: Series contains images, chiefly engravings and lithographs, of various practices, events, and themes related to the history of medicine. Arranged in alphabetical order by subject, and by box number within. The series is arranged by original topical groupings designated by library staff; new groups were also added for additions to the collection. The current divisions are: Advertisements; Anatomy; Apothecary Jars; Baths; Bindings; Bloodletting; Books, Texts, and Illustrations; Buildings; Cardiology; Caricature; Cartoons; Cemeteries; Chemistry; Childbirth; Circumcision; Embryology; Hospitals; Infant Care; Leeches; Manikins; Man, Medicine, and Work; Medical Chests; Medical Costumes; Medical Devices; Military Medicine; Miscellaneous; Natural Science; Nurses and Nursing; Operating Rooms; Pediatrics; Pharmacies; Physicians; Postcards; Psychology; Stages in the Growth of Modern Medicine; and Surgery. The largest series are Anatomy, Caricatures, Physicians, and Surgery.

As with other series, the predominant formats are engravings and other printed items (including postcards, posters, broadsides, and clippings), and 20th century photographic images, often reproductions of printed works. Images are also often accompanied by a slide or negative reproduction created by Medical Library staff as far back as the 1960s. Sizes range from small prints under 10x12 inches, to oversize items of up to 23x30 inches. The dimensions of oversize boxes are given in the container inventory.

Many of the items have been digitized and can be found through the Medical Center Library & Archives Historical Images in Medicine (HIM) database. Please contact the History of Medicine Curator for information on the digital images.

did.unittitle: Advertising cards for pharmaceutical products, 20th century

scopecontent.p: Nine large supplements with advertisements for antibiotics featuring lavishly colored illustrations of scenes from medical history across the centuries.

did.unittitle: Anatomical standing figures with successive layers of musculature, reproductions of engravings, 17th century

scopecontent.p: 20th century reproductions taking the form of black-and-white postcard-size images, taped onto two long pieces of hinged board, reproducing 17th century anatomical figures standing before a rural landscape with towns. When put together, the cards form a continuous image of successively flayed human figures against a panoramic background.

did.unittitle: Anatomy of the head - eyes, ears, brain: four historical views, 1698-1818

scopecontent.p: Four loose large black-and-white modern reproductions of engravings by Bartisch (1583), John Browne (1698), Le Cat (1744), and Soemmering (1818), published by Verlag.

did.unittitle: Illustrations of the human body, New York, 1857

scopecontent.p: Large chart, in color, with illustrations of the human musculature, organs, joints, and other parts; with advertisements for "olive tar" and for the J.R. Stafford's family receipt book.

did.unittitle: Human skeleton with musculature, untitled color engraving, 1800s

scopecontent.p: Large chart with hand-written annotations in French.

did.unittitle: Wong's app [?] atlas of master acupuncture points, 1975

scopecontent.p: Color prints, one for each view: frontal, side, and back. Includes lists for master points, angles of insertion, and code of meridians.

scopecontent.p: Pages from book, includes four illustrations of different bath scenes.

La maladie, black-and-white engraving on card stock, Paris, undated

scopecontent.p: Vignettes of the stages of a man's life. The most prominent is an older man seated at his desk surrounded by books and chemical apparatus. A skeleton leans over his shoulder. Drawn by Nanteuil; engraved by Colin.

did.unittitle: Poster of cover of book by/about Vesalius, by "Jeremy M"circa 2002
"Photo used for dedication program, May 1976" [black and white photo of stairwell as abstract spiral, unidentified building or location], undated
Heart murmur, by P. Hoffman, color etching, early half of 20th century

scopecontent.p: Shows physician bending with his ear to the back of a half-nude woman on bed to listen to her heart, disapproving older woman in background.

did.unittitle: Evolution of our knowledge of the heart and its diseases, chart with milestones and advances, black-and-white, mounted on board, 1938
Color illustration of cloaked man, by Spy, 19th century
Consilium medicum, black-and-white engraving of men debating around a table, F. Geyer, 19th century
Consilium medicum, with the supra-title, Kunstbeilage zum Riedel-Archiv, black-and-white engraving of men debating around a table, F. Geyer, 19th century, modern reproduction
Dr. Monsey, black-and-white engraving, Forster, published in European Magazine, 1789
Society of Pithotomists, black-and-white engraving, circa 1897 [Young chubby child as Asclepias/Bacchus astride barrel of drink, flanked by cat and owl]

scopecontent.p: According to note, drawing is by Max Brdel, medical illustrator and member of the Pithotomy Club at Johns Hopkins Hospital. The Pithotomy Club was an eating club. The drawing represents the birth of a new doctor (infant with wings), accompanied by learning (hat) and wisdom (owl). Pithos means "keg," otomy, "opening." Gift of James Semans, member of the Pithotomy Club.

did.unittitle: The company of undertakers... [physicians with various implements], English, 18th century

scopecontent.p: Was accompanied by card with note that gives the source as The Works of William Hogarth from the Original Plates, published by John Nichols, FSA, London, 1822.

did.unittitle: Physic, Men of the Day No. 62, by "Spy," Vanity Fair, 1873 Apr. 26

scopecontent.p: Title derived from note which says the subject is Alexander Hamilton (1739-1802), Professor of Midwifery at Edinburgh University.

did.unittitle: Scientific research! new discoveries in pneumaticks! or an experimental lecture on the powers of air [laboratory classroom at a "Royal Institute," with large audience of men and women watching three physicians experimenting with gases, with flatulent effects], color engraving, 1802
Set of 19th century caricatures of well-known scientists such as Darwin, Huxley, etc., with accompanying biographies, circa 1940s

scopecontent.p: Set of nine color matted reproductions. Most of the original works are by "Spy." Distributed by pharmaceutical company Petrolagar Laboratories.

did.unittitle: The reward of cruelty, "designed by W. Hogarth," 1751 [engraving of medical dissection of criminal's cadaver]

scopecontent.p: Was accompanied by card with note that gives the source as The Works of William Hogarth from the Original Plates, published by John Nichols, FSA, London, 1822.

Consultation de mdecins, 1823, by L. Boilly, matted color lithograph by Delpeck, Paris, between 1820-1830 [group of five young doctors, all examining one another]
Dr. Syntax with the Skimmington Riders, color engraving, Rowlandson, undated

scopecontent.p: Depicts the doctor on horseback, surrounded by a raucous crowd with pots, pans, and a drum, parading effigies through the street. Part of a series of engravings by Thomas Rowlandson titled "The Tours of Dr. Syntax."

did.unittitle: The doctor's dream, color engraving, Rowlandson, undated

scopecontent.p: Dr. Syntax, asleep in a library, while small figures with books for wings fly above him.

did.unittitle: Color drawing of man pointing to his side, modern reproduction, Nuremberg, 17th century?

scopecontent.p: Christ-like figure points to his upper abdomen, left side.

did.unittitle: Does it hurt me?--Does it hurt you!, [patient grabbing doctor's nose], black-and-white engraving, undated
"Esculape se mettant en garde pour defndre...contre tous les novateurs blonds en noirs, qui viennent pour l'attaquer ["Hippocrate" as physician with giant hypodermic], 19th century
"Amateurs excecutant une courante" [physicians in group playing "music" on medical devices], late 18th or early 19th century
The root of king's evil - n.b. to cure ye constitution of this evil, ye AXE must be laid to yet Root, color lithograph, England, 1835

scopecontent.p: Shows a bewigged man in his study, reading a book open to an etymology of "radical," confronted with imp in the shape of a medicinal root, who holds up placards about reform, plunder, and showing two stakes through the Magna Carta and the Bible. Seems to refer to English politics and definition of radical reform.

did.unittitle: Society of Pithotomists, 1897 [chubby child as Asclepius/Bacchus astride barrel of drink, flanked by cat and owl], black-and-white engraving, circa 1897

did.unittitle: Il caso interessante [group of doctors examining leg of beautiful woman], matted color lithograph, Italy, by P. Folli, early 20th century

Modern medical events, 1950 [humorous poster of history of medicine in North America]
Another form of mortsafe in Greyfriars Churchyard, Edinburgh, black-and-white photograph, early 20th century
Historical medical apparatuses from the London Science Museum: a chart (Dalton's elements), and one diagram, "Chrysopoeia," undated, modern black-and-white photographs

Illustration from Della Commare, Girolamo Mercurio, engraving depicting Caesarean section, circa 1642, modern black-and-white photograph
Physician seated on stool assisting birth, with two female attendants, consultation of stars in background, photo of black-and-white engraving, 17th century?

Post T[H]amar geminos vitales aedit in auras possitur ad poenas sic stat sententia Iudae, black-and-white engraving [Dutch?] [bedchamber of woman who just gave birth to twins, surrounded by female attendants], 17th century?

scopecontent.p: After the work by Martin Heemskerck, 16th century painter, Biblical story of Judah and Tamar, birth of Pharez and Zarah. Could also be by the painter himself.

did.unittitle: Birth of St. Edmund, color lithograph reproducing medieval illustration of bedchamber after birth, 19th century [H. Shaw, lithographer]

scopecontent.p: Woman in fur-trimmed jacket and gown is seated in bed-chamber, doctor in fur-trimmed coat and hat stands near her with his fingers on her pulse, gazing into an upheld flask. Date engraved on edge of tray with quill.

scopecontent.p: Scenes from a doctor's life include an emergency ward, cramming for exams, a new private practice, an anatomy lab, an African American home birth, a pediatric ward in a hospital, an ambulance call, street emergency, a clinic with working-class patients, and others.

did.unittitle: A student's dream, print reproduction of early 20th century black-and-white photograph

scopecontent.p: A physician is lying asleep on examination table, surrounded by skeletons in the role of physicians/examiners.

did.unittitle: Facsimile of Hebrew manuscript text, physician's oath, circa 6th century AD, published in 1952

scopecontent.p: Physician's oath, found at the end of a medical work by Asaph the physician, who lived in Israel in 6th century AD. Facsimile of original Oxford Hebrew Ms 2138. Text is reproduced in Hebrew script on one side and in English on the other. Red initial letters. Matted with two windows.

did.unittitle: [Physician, woman, and skeleton], color lithograph or etching, circa 1920s

scopecontent.p: Image of physician or surgeon in white coat with cap, supporting a nude woman with long hair, pushes away a skeleton who is kneeling and grasping her by the legs. Signed by unidentified artist.

did.unittitle: The Doctor and His Patient, by Gerard Dou (1613-1675)

scopecontent.p: Carbon print photograph of painting, from Royal Gallery of Buckingham Palace. Physician in fur hat and robes gazes upward at liquid in glass globe, while holding wrist of female patient, also in fur-trimmed garments.

userestrict.p: Carbon print emulsion is cracked - handle with care.

did.unittitle: Le paralitique servy [sic] par ses enfans / The paralytic served by his children. Presented to the Earle of [Sweting?], by his most obedient servant [Cartiche?], circa late 18th century

scopecontent.p: Engraving after painting by Greuze. An old man on his sickbed is served food and drink by his many children.

Carbon print photograph of painting, from the Hermitage at St. Petersburg. Portrait of sick woman in fur-trimmed garments, seated in large chair, while physician in black robes to her right gazes at liquid in glass globe.

did.unittitle: Porcelain figures, undated, from The Wellcome Historical Medical Museum, London, modern color postcards

scopecontent.p: Subjects include Meissen figures of Florence Nightingale, a gout sufferer,a quack doctor, a faun and baby, and alchemy.

did.unittitle: The Four Stages of Cruelty, William Hogarth, London, 1799

scopecontent.p: Four engravings by T. Cook from Hogarth's designs: First stage of cruelty; Second stage of cruelty; Cruelty in perfection; and The reward of cruelty. The detailed scenes depict a fictional character's progressive cruelty to animals, leading to murder, hanging, and a grisly end on a dissection table. Around the central character in each engraving are shown many other acts of cruelty by other individuals, and numerous symbolic elements.

did.unittitle: Surgeon operating on a soldier, Walther Hermann Ryff, Frankfurt, black-and-white engraving, 1541

scopecontent.p: From Stadt und Feldtbuch. Man treats another's head wound while another man with arm in a sling stands by; a battle rages in the background. Date is taken from penciled note.

did.unittitle: Barber-surgeon operating behind a man's ear, Lucas van Leyden, small black-and-white engraving mounted on modern paper leaf, 1523/1524

scopecontent.p: From Bades-Chirurg.

did.unittitle: Der Barbier/The Barber, black-and-white engraving, Carse, 1800s?

scopecontent.p: A barber-surgeon operates on a man's arm; an onlooker stands nearby. Original painting is by Broumer.

did.unittitle: L'homme la fourchette, M.Lasseur, black-and-white engraving, circa 1885

scopecontent.p: From Hygine et mdecine des deux sexes. Surgeon operates on a man who has swallowed a fork. shows two inset views of patient and stomach with fork inside. Drawn by Stablo.

did.unittitle: Surgeon operating on top of screaming patient's head, from Rotterdam Museum, Frans Hals (?), small sepia photo reproduction of painting, undated

scopecontent.p: Image portrays surgery performed with ether as anaesthetic; modern color glossy reproduction of painting.

did.unittitle: The history of anesthesia, posters, circa 1944

scopecontent.p: Black-and-white "study charts" numbered 1 to 4, with many illustrations and text explicating the history of anesthesia; central inset advertises the 1944 Paramount Pictures film The Great Moment, about the Boston dentist W.T.G. Morton who first used anesthesia.

did.unittitle: Bronze Roman surgical instruments, circa 3rd century A.D., modern black-and-white photograph

scopecontent.p: Illustrations were originally published by Denis Diderot and Jean D'Alembert around 1770 (online source).

did.unittitle: Chirurgie, copy of plate 35 from above, 18th century
